mn116:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rajagaha, on the Isigili Mountain.
mn116:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
mn116:2.1: “Mendicants, do you see that Mount Vebhara?”
mn116:2.3: “It used to have a different label and description.
mn116:2.4: Do you see that Mount Pandava?”
mn116:2.6: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:2.7: Do you see that Mount Vepulla?”
mn116:2.9: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:2.10: Do you see that Mount Vulture’s Peak?”
mn116:2.12: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:2.13: Do you see that Mount Isigili?”
mn116:3.1: “It used to have exactly the same label and description.
mn116:3.2: Once upon a time, five hundred Independent Buddhas dwelt for a long time on this Isigili.
mn116:3.3: They were seen entering the mountain, but after entering were seen no more.
mn116:3.4: When people noticed this they said:
mn116:3.6: That’s how it came to be known as Isigili, the “seer-swallower”.
mn116:3.7: I shall declare the names of the Independent Buddhas;
mn116:3.8: I shall extol the names of the Independent Buddhas;
mn116:3.9: I shall teach the names of the Independent Buddhas.
mn116:3.10: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn116:4.1: “The independent Buddhas who dwelt for a long time on this Isigili were named Arittha,
mn116:5.1: Those saintly beings, untroubled, <j>with no need for hope,
mn116:5.4: the supreme persons, free of thorns.
mn116:6.3: Independent Buddhas, <j>enders of the conduit to rebirth;
mn116:6.4: and Hingu and Hinga the mighty.
mn116:6.5: Two sages named Jali, and Atthaka;
mn116:6.6: then the awakened one Kosala, then Subahu;
mn116:6.8: right and true, stainless and astute.
mn116:6.9: Kala and Upakala, Vijita and Jita,
mn116:6.10: Anga and Panga, and Guttijita too;
mn116:6.11: Passin gave up attachment, suffering’s root,
mn116:6.15: Manomaya, and Bandhuma the cutter of conceit,
mn116:6.16: then Adhimutta, and Ketuma the immaculate.
mn116:6.22: another sage, Sayha of peerless effort.
mn116:6.23: There are twelve Anandas, Nandas, and Upanandas,
mn116:6.24: and Bharadvaja, bearing his final body.
mn116:6.27: Tissa and Upatissa, <j>who’ve both cut the bonds to rebirth,
mn116:6.28: Upasidari and Sidari, who’ve both cut off craving.
mn116:6.29: Mangala was awakened, free of greed,
mn116:6.30: Usabha cut the net, the root of suffering,
mn116:6.31: Upanita who attained the state of peace,
mn116:6.35: Manatthaddha, beautiful and free of greed,
mn116:6.36: and the Buddha Kanha, his mind well freed.
mn116:7.1: These and other mighty ones <j>awakened independently,
mn116:7.2: enders of the conduit to rebirth—
mn116:7.3: honor these great seers <j>who have slipped all chains,
